list.title: Question 3
list.content: A circle of radius 3 and centre (0,3) is drawn on an Argand diagram. The tangent to the circle from the point B$(0,9)$ meets the circle at the point A as shown. Let $w = \vv{\mathrm{OA}}$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04bae060-5e07-43ac-8364-cfc8cd354822/images/e865f15b-927e-4ac3-83c8-71f1486f972f/756bc10d49856365edc8188e18631d432452e02d.svg) - Show that $|w| = 3\sqrt{3}$. [2] - Find $\arg w$. [2] - Hence write $w$ in the form $a+b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Given that the angle between a tangent and a radius is a right angle, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04bae060-5e07-43ac-8364-cfc8cd354822/images/c4a50bb7-b50d-4dd2-a81a-400c65a24109/e572903f13ea5ca7d33e50badc186e738f21ec73.svg)


  Using the right triangle ABC, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.4em} \cos(\text{A\^{C}B}) &= \dfrac{3}{6} \hspace{3em} \left(=\dfrac{1}{2}\right) \\[6pt]
  \text{A\^{C}B} &= \dfrac{\pi}{3} \\[6pt]
  \text{A\^{C}O} &= \dfrac{2\pi}{3}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the
cosine rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.4em} |w|^2 &= 3^2 + 3^2 - 2(3)(3)\cos \Big(\dfrac{2\pi}{3}\Big) \\[3pt]
  |w|^2 &= 18 - 18\hspace{-0.1em}\left[-\dfrac{1}{2}\right] \\[6pt]
  |w|^2 &= 27 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{|w| = 3\sqrt{3}} \hspace{0.9em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/04bae060-5e07-43ac-8364-cfc8cd354822/images/0be7156c-9e85-4803-88bb-febc8c38dfed/c956da10fdd9a0dd23ce23a1defc574f970f2c67.svg)


- Using the isosceles triangle OAC, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \text{A\^{O}C} &= \dfrac{1}{2}\hspace{0.05em}(\pi - \text{A\^{C}O}) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}\bigg[\pi - \dfrac{2\pi}{3}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\pi}{6}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the argument of $w$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} \arg w &= \dfrac{\pi}{2} - \text{A\^{O}C} \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\pi}{2} - \dfrac{\pi}{6} \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{\pi}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we write $w$ in Cartesian form, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.4em} w &= 3\sqrt{3}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right) \\[9pt]
  &= 3\sqrt{3}\bigg[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right)\hspace{-0.2em}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= 3\sqrt{3}\bigg[\dfrac{1}{2} + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\bigg] \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{3\sqrt{3}}{2} + \dfrac{9}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 4
list.content: In this question give all angles in radians. Let $z = 1 + 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $w = 4 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$. - Find $z+w$. [1] - Find: - $|z+w|$; - $\arg(z+w)$. [3] - Find $\theta$, the angle shown on the diagram below. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3f0968bc-fcf5-46b9-9ca5-4e6c802b5585/images/e5aae188-d040-41e8-b169-2d50a1a756f5/9f1b9b167af97e4b2c9ee84b7c9014f2cdaf63c7.svg)
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  z+w &= (1+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) + (4 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[6pt]
  &= (1+4) + (2+1){\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 5 + 3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The modulus of $z+w$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    |z+w| &= \sqrt{5^2 + 3^2} \hspace{6.3em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 5.83}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The argument of $z+w$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \arg(z+w) &= \tan^{-1}(3/5) \hspace{7.25em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 0.540}\end{aligned}
    $$


- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.7em} \theta &= \arg z - \arg (z+w) \\[6pt]
  &= \tan^{-1}(2/1) - \tan^{-1}(3/5) \\[6pt]
  &= (1.107148\dots) - (0.540419\dots) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.567}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Consider the complex number $z = \dfrac{w_1}{w_2}$ where $w_1 = \sqrt{2} + \sqrt{6}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $w_2 = 3 + \sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$. - Express $w_1$ and $w_2$ in modulus-argument form and write down - the modulus of $z$; - the argument of $z$. [4] - Find the smallest positive integer value of $n$ such that $z^n$ is a real number. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we express $w_1$ and $w_2$ in modulus-argument form, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{w_1 = 2\sqrt{2}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right)} \hspace{1.5em} \text{and} \hspace{1.5em}  \answer{w_2 = 2\sqrt{3}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  
  - Hence the modulus of $z$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    |z| &= \dfrac{|w_1|}{|w_2|} \hspace{1.3em} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{\bcancel{2}\sqrt{2}}{\bcancel{2}\sqrt{3}} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{\sqrt{6}}{3}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Hence the argument of $z$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.5em} \arg z &= \arg w_1 - \arg w_2 \\[10pt]
    &= \dfrac{\pi}{3} - \dfrac{\pi}{6} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{\pi}{6}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- The $n$th power of $z$ is a real number if

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9em} \sin \left(\arg \left(z^n\right)\right) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  \sin \left(n\arg z\right) &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{by de Moivre's theorem}] \\[3pt]
  \sin \left(\dfrac{n\pi}{6}\right) &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a) (ii)}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the smallest $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$ such that $z^n$ is a real
number is  $\answer{n = 6}$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Let $z = 2+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $w = 1-2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$. - Find $zw$. [2] - Illustrate $z$, $w$ and $zw$ on the same Argand diagram. [3] - Let $\theta$ be the angle between $zw$ and $w$. Find $\theta$, giving your answer in radians.[3]
list.markScheme:
- The product of $z$ and $w$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  zw &= (2+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})(1-2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[6pt]
  &= 2-4{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}+2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 4-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we illustrate $z$, $w$ and $zw$ on the same Argand diagram, we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d16706e0-5faa-41a5-804d-8aaa9391a8e7/images/ed6df27d-739a-4366-8e0a-514cde709407/96f14dbc4defd6873946ae02a45c2e643f791342.svg)


- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg w &= \tan^{-1}((-2)/1) \\[6pt]
  &= -1.107148\dots \hspace{1.3em} \end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg zw &= \tan^{-1}((-3)/4) \\[6pt]
  &= -0.643501\dots \hspace{1.8em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8em} \theta &= |\arg w| - |\arg zw| \\[6pt]
  &= (1.107148\dots) - (0.643501\dots) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.464}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Let $z = re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{6}}$ where $r \in \mathbb{R}^+$. - For $r = \sqrt{3}$, - express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in the form $a+b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$; - draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/25f0d8f7-978f-4d4f-985d-c76b02b32a2c/images/9d23235e-6a7d-47d4-bc54-39e966a1c5c6/633c15de281dbaeb852d4279b825abc3a94854e8.svg) - Given that the integer powers of $w = \dfrac{z}{6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}$ lie on a unit circle centred at the origin, find the value of $r$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - If we express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in Cartesian form, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4em} z^2 &= 3e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{3}} \\[10pt]
    &= 3\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos\Big(\frac{\pi}{3}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\frac{\pi}{3}\Big)\Big] \\[4pt]
    &\answer{=\dfrac{3}{2} + \dfrac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
    $$

    and

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5.3em} z^3 &= 3\sqrt{3}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{2}} \\[10pt]
    &= 3\sqrt{3}\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}\Big)\Big] \\[10pt]
    &\answer{=0+3\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram, we
have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/25f0d8f7-978f-4d4f-985d-c76b02b32a2c/images/ecfbb324-4335-4248-af17-503361e08908/ecdfaa8e1f1031e684d45d25638e79596842fb1a.svg)



- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}| &= \sqrt{6^2 + 2^2} \hspace{2.2em} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{40} \\[6pt]
  &= 2\sqrt{10}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the properties of modulus,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |w^k| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}$}]  \\[16pt]
  |w|^k &= 1 \\[17pt]
  |w| &= 1 \\[15pt]
  \hspace{3.9em} \Big|\dfrac{z}{6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\Big| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [w = z/(6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})] \\[8pt]
  \dfrac{|z|}{|6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}|} &= 1 \\[9pt]
  \dfrac{r}{2\sqrt{10}} &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{r = 2\sqrt{10}} \hspace{1.3em}
  $$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Consider the equation $\dfrac{3z}{5-z^{*}}=\text{i}$, where
$z=x+\text{i}y$ and $x$, $y \in \mathbb{R}$.
Find the value of $x$ and the value of $y$.
list.markScheme:
We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{3z}{5-z^{*}}&=\text{i} \\[12pt]
\dfrac{3(x+\text{i}y)}{5-(x-\text{i}y)}&= \text{i}\\[12pt]
\dfrac{3x+3y\text{i}}{5-x+y\text{i}}&=\text{i}\\[12pt]
3x+3y\text{i}&=\text{i}(5-x+y\text{i}) \\[12pt]
3x+3y\text{i}&=5\text{i}-x\text{i}-y\\[12pt]
3x+3y\text{i}&=-y+(5-x)\text{i}\end{aligned}
$$

Complex numbers can be
equal only if their real and imaginary parts are equal.
Equating the real
parts, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
3x&=-y \\[8pt]
y&=-3x \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

Equating the imaginary parts, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
3y&=5-x \\[8pt]
3(-3x)&=5-x \hspace{4em} [\hspace{0.1em}\text{by equation (1)}\hspace{0.1em}]\\[8pt]
-9x&=5-x\\[8pt]
&\hspace{-0.55em}\answer{x=-\dfrac{5}{8}}\\
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting the value of $x$ in equation $(1)$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
y&=-3\left(-\dfrac{5}{8}\right)\\[12pt]
&\hspace{-0.55em}\answer{y=\dfrac{15}{8}}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Let $z = re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{3}}$ where $r \in \mathbb{R}^+$. - For $r = \sqrt{2}$, - express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in the form $a+b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$; - draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59a008f3-3d50-44d9-869a-42b4824709d2/images/9f941692-8f3e-4cfd-9d12-fc50abaa27ce/7e711daec273ec9c0f630b852aae229a5a09d558.svg) - Given that the integer powers of $w = (3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})\hspace{0.05em}z$ lie on a unit circle centred at the origin, find the value of $r$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - If we express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in Cartesian form, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5.5em} z^2 &= 2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{2\pi}{3}} \\[9pt]
    &= 2\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos\Big(\frac{2\pi}{3}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\frac{2\pi}{3}\Big)\Big] \\[9pt]
    &\answer{=-1 + \sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \end{aligned}
    $$

    and

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} z^3 &= 2\sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\pi} \\[9pt]
    &= 2\sqrt{2}\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos \pi + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \pi \Big] \\[9pt]
    &\answer{=-2\sqrt{2} + 0{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram, we
have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59a008f3-3d50-44d9-869a-42b4824709d2/images/b1595772-f8bb-4154-802a-3fe48a2a9de8/ee3e2d0e8670f88c39e4d0221f05849bcdba3ebd.svg)



- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}| &= \sqrt{3^2 + (-3)^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{18} \\[6pt]
  &= 3\sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the properties of modulus,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |w^k| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}$}]  \\[13pt]
  |w|^k &= 1 \\[14pt]
  |w| &= 1 \\[14pt]
  \hspace{3.1em} |(3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})z| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [w = (3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})z] \\[14pt]
  |3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}||z| &= 1 \\[12pt]
  3\sqrt{2}\hspace{0.05em}r &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{r = \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{6}} \hspace{1.4em}
  $$

list.title: Question 10
list.content: The complex numbers $z$ and $w$ correspond to the points A and B as shown on the diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9662101a-846e-4330-acd8-a3cb1cce180f/images/03879786-889a-461a-8062-d630c448493e/0c46fa70e78de8ef6fa11a8d28566cc1742d4a83.svg) - Find the exact value of $|z - w|$. [2] - - Find the exact perimeter of triangle AOB. - Find the exact area of triangle AOB. [4]
list.markScheme:
- Using the cosine rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} |z - w|^2 &= |z|^2 + |w|^2 - 2|z||w|\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) \\[6pt]
  |z - w|^2 &= 5^2 + 5^2 - 2(5)(5)\hspace{-0.1em} \bigg[\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\bigg] \\[10pt]
  |z - w|^2 &= 25(2-\sqrt{3}) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{|z - w| = \textstyle 5\sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}}} \hspace{4.3em}
  $$

- 
  - The exact perimeter of triangle AOB is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \text{perimeter} &= |z| + |w| + |z-w| \\[6pt]
    &= 5 + 5 + \textstyle 5\sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \textstyle 10 + 5\sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The exact area of triangle AOB is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.1em} \text{area} &= \dfrac{1}{2}|z||w|\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{2}(5)(5)\hspace{-0.1em}\bigg[\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg] \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{25}{4}}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Points A and B represent the complex numbers $z_1 = \sqrt{3} - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $z_2 = -3 - 3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ as shown on the Argand diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9d9e505c-2db3-40c7-a42d-55c3cac6ef7c/images/d468bfe1-7366-4e12-ad66-62a216488065/b9acbcc9be3dbe232f939a960c2a1907744b9b96.svg) - Find the angle AOB. [3] - Find the argument of $z_1z_2$. [1] - Given that the real powers of $pz_1z_2$, for $p > 0$, all lie on a unit circle centred at the origin, find the exact value of $p$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg z_1 &= \tan^{-1}\left(\hspace{-0.2em}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\hspace{-0.1em}\right) \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{\pi}{6}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg z_2 &= \tan^{-1}(1) \hspace{0.9em} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\pi}{4} - \pi \\[8pt]
  &= -\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.3em} \text{A\^{O}B} &= |\arg z_2| - |\arg z_1| \\[10pt]
  &= \dfrac{3\pi}{4} - \dfrac{\pi}{6} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{7\pi}{12}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The argument of $z_1z_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg(z_1z_2) &= \arg z_1 + \arg z_2 \\[10pt]
  &= -\dfrac{\pi}{6} - \dfrac{3\pi}{4} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= -\dfrac{11\pi}{12}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.2em} |z_1| &= \textstyle \sqrt{(\sqrt{3})^2 + (-1)^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{4} \\[8pt]
  &= 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.1em} |z_2| &= \sqrt{(-3)^2 + (-3)^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{18} \\[6pt]
  &= 3\sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the properties of modulus,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.7em} |(pz_1z_2)^x| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$}] \\[12pt]
  |pz_1z_2|^x &= 1 \\[12pt]
  |pz_1z_2| &= 1 \\[12pt]
  |p||z_1||z_2| &= 1 \\[12pt]
  p\hspace{0.05em}(2)(3\sqrt{2}) &= 1  \hspace{3em} [\text{since $p > 0$}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{p = \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{12}} \hspace{2.6em}
  $$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
The complex numbers $w$ and $z$ satisfy the equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{z}{w} &= {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}, \\[6pt]
w^\ast + 2z &= 4 + 5{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}.\end{aligned}
$$

Find $w$ and $z$ in the form
$a + b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where
$a, b \in \mathbb{Z}$.
list.markScheme:
We have

$$
\hspace{1.5em} z = {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}w \\
$$

and

$$
w^\ast + 2z = 4 + 5{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\qref{(1)}
$$

Substituting $w = x + y{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and
$z = {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(x + y{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})$
in the equation $(1)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
(x + y{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})^\ast + 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(x + y{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) &= 4 + 5{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\\[6pt]
(x - y{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) + \left(-2y + 2x{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\right) &= 4 + 5{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\\[6pt]
(x - 2y) + (2x - y){\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}&= 4 + 5{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, comparing real and imaginary parts of the equation $(2)$, we get

$$
\begin{array}{rcl}
x - 2y &=& 4 \\[8pt]
2x - y &=& 5
\end{array} \hspace{1.5em} \qref{(3)}
$$

Solving the system of equations
$(3)$ for $x$ and $y$, we obtain $x = 2$ and $y = -1$.
Hence we find
$\answer{w = 2-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}$
and
$\answer{z = 1+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}$

list.title: Question 15
list.content: Consider the equation $z^4-6z^3+cz^2-30z+13=0$ where $z \in \mathbb{C}$ and $c \in \mathbb{R}$. Three of the roots of the equation are $2-3i$, $\alpha$ and $\alpha^4$, where $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find the value of $\alpha$.[4] - Hence, or otherwise, find the value of $c$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- Since $2-3i$ is a root its conjugate $2+3i$ is a root too.
  Now, using the formula for the product of the roots, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \text{product of roots}&=(-1)^4\dfrac{a_0}{a_4}\\[6pt]
  (2-3i)\cdot(2+3i)\cdot \alpha \cdot \alpha^4 &=(1)\dfrac{13}{1}\\[8pt]
  13\cdot \alpha^5&=13\\[8pt]  
  &\hspace{-0.65em}\tcbhighmath{\alpha =1} \hspace{4em}[\text{since $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$}]
  \end{align*}
  $$

- The complex polynomial can be factorised as

  $$
  \begin{align*} 
   p(x)&=(x-(2+3i))(x-(2-3i))(x-1)(x-1)\\[8pt]
   &=(x^2-4x+13)(x-1)^2\\[8pt]
   &=(x^2-4x+13)(x^2-2x+1)\\[8pt]
   &=x^4-6x^3+22x^2-30x+13
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore, we conclude that $\hspace{0.29em}\tcbhighmath{c=22}$

  Hence the roots of the equation $z^3 = -64$, in modulus-argument form, are

list.content: Consider the complex numbers $u = 1 + 2 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $v = 2 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$. - Given that $\dfrac{1}{u} + \dfrac{1}{v} = \dfrac{6\sqrt{2}}{w}$, express $w$ in the form $a + b {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$. [4] - Find $w^\ast$ and express it in the form $re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\theta}$. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting $u = 1+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and
$v = 2+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ in the given equation,
we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.1em} \dfrac{6\sqrt{2}}{w} &= \dfrac{1}{u} + \dfrac{1}{v} \\[6pt]
  &=  \dfrac{1}{1 + 2 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} + \dfrac{1}{2 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[6pt]
  &=  \dfrac{1}{1 + 2 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\cdot\dfrac{1 - 2 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{1 - 2 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} + \dfrac{1}{2 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\cdot\dfrac{2 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{2 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1 - 2 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{5} + \dfrac{2 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{5} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{3 - 3 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{5} \qref{(1)} \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $w$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  w &= \dfrac{30\sqrt{2}}{3 - 3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[5pt]
  &= \dfrac{10\sqrt{2}}{1 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\cdot\dfrac{1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[5pt]
  &= \dfrac{10\sqrt{2}\hspace{0.05em}(1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})}{2} \\[11pt]
  &= 5\sqrt{2}\hspace{0.05em}(1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[14pt]
  &\answer{= 5\sqrt{2} + 5\sqrt{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \hspace{4em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The conjugate of $w$ is

  \begin{aligned}

  &\answer{= 10\hspace{0.05em}e^{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{4}}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by Euler's formula}]\end{aligned}

list.content:
Consider the equation $2z^4 + az^3 + bz^2 +cz + d = 0$, where
$a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{R}$ and $z \in \mathbb{C}$. Two of the roots of
the equation are $\log_2 10$ and
${\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5}$ and the sum of all the
roots is $4 + \log_25$.
Show that $15a + d + 90 = 0$.
list.markScheme:
Since ${\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5}$ is a root, its
conjugate $- {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5}$ is also a
root of the equation.
If $z_4$ is the fourth root of the equation, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bcancel{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5}} + (- \bcancel{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5}}) + \log_2 10 + z_4 &= 4 + \log_25 \hspace{2.75em} [\text{sum of roots}] \\[6pt]
z_4 &= 4 + \log_25 - \log_2 10 \\[6pt]
z_4 &= 4 + \cancel{\log_25} - (\log_22 + \cancel{\log_25}) \\[6pt]
z_4 &= 4 - 1 \hspace{2.75em} [\text{since $\log_2 2 = 1$}] \\[6pt]
z_4 &= 3\end{aligned}
$$

Using Vieta's formulas, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\dfrac{a}{2} &= 4 + \log_25 \hspace{2.75em} [\text{sum of roots}] \\[6pt]
a &= -8 - 2\log_25\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.4em} (-1)^4\bigg[\dfrac{d}{2}\bigg] &= ({\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5})(-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sqrt{5})(\log_2 10)(3) \hspace{2.75em} [\text{product of roots}] \\[6pt]
d &= 30\log_210\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} 15a + d + 90 &= 15(-8 - 2\log_25) + 30\log_210 + 90 \\[6pt] 
&= -120 - \bcancel{30\log_25}  +  30\log_22 + \bcancel{30\log_25} + 90 \\[6pt] 
&= -120 + 30 + 90 \hspace{2.75em} [\text{since $\log_2 2 = 1$}] \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 0}\end{aligned}
$$

list.content: Consider the complex numbers $z_1 = 3 \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}(\ang{120})$ and $z_2 = 2 + 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$. - Calculate $\dfrac{z_1}{z_2}$ giving your answer both in modulus-argument form and Cartesian form. [7] - Use your results from part (a) to find the exact value of $\sin \ang{15}\cdot\,\sin \ang{45} \cdot\,\sin \ang{75}$, giving your answer in the form $\dfrac{\sqrt{a}}{b}$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. [5]
list.markScheme:
- If we express $z_1$ in Cartesian form, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  z_1 &= 3 \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}(\ang{120}) \\[12pt]
  &= 3 \cos (\ang{120}) + 3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (\ang{120}) \\[4pt]
  &= -\dfrac{3}{2} + \dfrac{3\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{2} \\[4pt]
  &= \dfrac{3}{2}(-1+\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we express $z_2$ in modulus-argument form, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.4em} z_2 &= 2 + 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\\[8pt]
  &= 2(1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[6pt]
  &= 2\sqrt{2}\hspace{0.05em}(\cos(\ang{45}) +{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin(\ang{45})) \\[6pt]
  &= 2\sqrt{2}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}(\ang{45}) \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if we calculate $\dfrac{z_1}{z_2}$ giving answer in
modulus-argument form, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{z_1}{z_2} &= \dfrac{3 \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}(\ang{120})}{2\sqrt{2}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}(\ang{45})} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{3\sqrt{2}}{4}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}(\ang{75})} \hspace{2.3em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if we calculate $\dfrac{z_1}{z_2}$ giving answer in Cartesian
form, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \dfrac{z_1}{z_2} &= \dfrac{\frac{3}{2}(-1+\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})}{2 + 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\frac{3}{2}(-1+\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})}{2 + 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\cdot \dfrac{2-2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{2-2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{3(-1+\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})(1 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})}{(2 + 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})(2 - 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{-3 + 3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}+ 3\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}+ 3\sqrt{3}}{4 + 4} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{3(\sqrt{3} - 1)}{8} + \dfrac{3(\sqrt{3} + 1)}{8}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we equate the two expressions for $\dfrac{z_1}{z_2}$ from part
(a), we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{3\sqrt{2}}{4}\cos(\ang{75}) + \dfrac{3\sqrt{2}}{4}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin(\ang{75}) &= \dfrac{3(\sqrt{3} - 1)}{8} + \dfrac{3(\sqrt{3} + 1)}{8}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \cos \ang{75} &= \dfrac{4}{3\sqrt{2}}\cdot\dfrac{3(\sqrt{3} - 1)}{8} \hspace{0.1em} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}-1}{2\sqrt{2}} \end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sin \ang{75} &= \dfrac{4}{3\sqrt{2}}\cdot\dfrac{3(\sqrt{3} + 1)}{8} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}+1}{2\sqrt{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1em} \sin \ang{15}\cdot\, \sin \ang{45} \cdot\, \sin \ang{75} &= \cos \ang{75}\cdot\, \sin \ang{45} \cdot\, \sin \ang{75} \\[9pt]
  &=  \dfrac{\sqrt{3}-1}{2\sqrt{2}}\cdot \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\cdot \dfrac{\sqrt{3}+1}{2\sqrt{2}} \\[3pt]
  &= \dfrac{(3-1)\sqrt{2}}{16} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{8}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 23
list.content: Consider $w = \dfrac{z - 1}{z + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}$ where $z = x + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}y$ and ${\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}= \sqrt{-1}$. - If $z = {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$, - write $w$ in the form $r\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\theta$; - find the value of $w^{14}$. [5] - Show that in general, $$ w = \dfrac{(x^2 - x + y^2 + y) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(y - x + 1)}{x^2 + (y + 1)^2} $$ [4] - Find condition under which $\mathrm{Re}(w) = 1$. [2] - State condition under which $w$ is: - real; - purely imaginary. [2] - Find the modulus of $z$ given that $\arg w = \dfrac{\pi}{4}$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Substituting $z = {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ in the
expression for $w$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    w &= \dfrac{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}- 1}{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}+ {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[5pt]
    &= \dfrac{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}- 1}{2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\cdot\dfrac{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[5pt]
    &= \dfrac{1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{2} \\[5pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{1}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, if we express $w$ given by $(1)$ in modulus-argument
form, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    w &= \dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{1}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\bigg[\dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2} + \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\bigg] \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right)\right] \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using de Moivre's theorem, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    w^{14} &= \left[\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right)\right]^{14} \\[5pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{2^7} \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\Big(\dfrac{7\pi}{2}\Big) \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{128}\left(-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\right) \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= - \dfrac{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{128}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Substituting $z = x + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}y$ in the
expression for $w$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  w &= \dfrac{(x + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}y) - 1}{(x + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}y) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{(x-1) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}y}{x  + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(y + 1)} \cdot \dfrac{x  - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(y + 1)}{x  - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(y + 1)} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{x(x - 1) + y(y + 1) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}[xy - (x-1)(y+1)]}{x^2 + (y+1)^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{(x^2 - x) + (y^2 + y) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}[\cancel{xy} - \cancel{xy} - x + y + 1]}{x^2 + (y+1)^2} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{(x^2 - x + y^2 + y) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(y - x + 1)}{x^2 + (y+1)^2}} \hspace{3em} [(x,y) \neq (0,-1)] \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Hence $\mathrm{Re}(w) = 1$ if

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{x^2 - x + y^2 + y}{x^2 + (y+1)^2} &= 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{by $(2)$}] \\[6pt]
  x^2 - x + y^2 + y &= x^2 + (y+1)^2 \\[12pt]
  x^2 - x + y^2 + y &= x^2 + y^2 + 2y + 1 \hspace{1.2em} \\[12pt]
  -x &= y + 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{12.9em}\answer{y = - x - 1} \hspace{3em} [(x,y) \neq (0,-1)]
  $$

- 
  - $w$ is real if
$\answer{y - x + 1 = 0}$
where $(x,y) \neq (0,-1)$.
  - $w$ is purely imaginary if
$\answer{x^2 - x + y^2 + y  = 0 \text{ and } y - x + 1 \neq 0}$

- Given that $\arg w = \dfrac{\pi}{4}$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \tan \hspace{0.05em}(\arg w) &= \dfrac{y - x + 1}{x^2 - x + y^2 + y} \\[3pt]
  1 &= \dfrac{y - x + 1}{x^2 - x + y^2 + y} \\[7pt]
  x^2 - x + y^2 + y &= y - x + 1 \\[13.5pt]
  x^2 + y^2 &= 1 \\[12pt]
  \sqrt{x^2 + y^2} &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{|z| = 1} \hspace{0.8em}
  $$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
On an Argand diagram, the complex numbers
$z_1 = 2 + 2\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$,
$z_2 = 1 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $z_3 = z_1z_2$ are
represented by the vertices of a triangle.
The exact area of the triangle can be expressed in the form
$p+\sqrt{q}$. Find the value of $p$ and of $q$.
list.markScheme:
We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.1em} |z_1| &= \textstyle \sqrt{2^2+(2\sqrt{3})^2} \\[6pt]
&= 4 \\[12pt]
|z_2| &= \sqrt{1^2+(-1)^2} \\[6pt]
&= \sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\arg z_1 &= \tan^{-1}(2\sqrt{3}/2) \\[6pt]
&= \ang{60} \\[12pt]
\arg z_2 &= \tan^{-1}(-1/1) \\[6pt]
&= -\ang{45}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using the property of modulus, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
|z_3| &= |z_1z_2| \\[6pt]
&= |z_1||z_2| \hspace{2.1em} \\[6pt]
&= 4\sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\arg z_3 &= \arg(z_1z_2) \\[6pt]
&= \arg z_1 + \arg z_2 \\[6pt]
&= \ang{15}\end{aligned}
$$

If we sketch the triangle whose vertices represent $z_1$, $z_2$ and
$z_3$ on an Argand diagram, we have
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9d725016-9066-4b8c-ac95-c47814030441/images/d6a47e5a-26b2-4956-8144-2fd2e75f4f4d/e1e467a933ff283d4afc5581ecd27d102258be6b.svg)


Hence the area of the triangle ABC is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{area(A\^{B}C)} &= \text{area(A\^{O}C)} + \text{area(B\^{O}C)} - \text{area(A\^{O}B)} \\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(4\sqrt{2})\sin \ang{45} + \dfrac{1}{2}(\sqrt{2})(4\sqrt{2})\sin \ang{60} - \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(\sqrt{2})\sin \left(\ang{60}+\ang{45}\right) \\[10pt]
&= (8\sqrt{2})\left(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) + 4 \left(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) - 2\sqrt{2}\,\Big(\sin \left(\ang{60}\right)\cos(\ang{45})+\cos(\ang{60})\sin(\ang{45}) \Big)\\[8pt]
&= 8+2\sqrt{3}-2\sqrt{2}\left(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\dfrac{1}{2}\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\\[10pt]
&= 7+\sqrt{3}\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,
$\answer{p=7}$and$\answer{q=3}$

list.title: Question 26
list.content: Let $z = \cos \theta + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \theta$, for $-\dfrac{\pi}{4} < \theta < \dfrac{\pi}{4}$. - - Find $z^3$ using the binomial theorem. - Use de Moivre's theorem to show that $\cos 3\theta = 4\cos^3\theta - 3\cos \theta$ and $\sin 3\theta = 3\sin\theta-4\sin^3\theta$. [8] - Hence show that $\dfrac{\sin 3\theta - \sin \theta}{\cos 3\theta + \cos \theta} = \tan \theta$. [6] - Given that $\sin \theta = \dfrac{1}{3}$, find the exact value of $\tan 3\theta$. [5]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Using the binomial theorem, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    z^3 &= (\cos \theta + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \theta)^3 \\[6pt]
    &= \cos^3 \theta + 3\cos^2 \theta\hspace{0.1em}({\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \theta) + 3 \cos \theta\hspace{0.1em}({\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \theta)^2 + ({\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \theta)^3 \\[6pt]
    &= \cos^3 \theta + 3 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\cos^2 \theta \sin \theta - 3 \cos \theta \sin^2 \theta - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin^3 \theta \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= (\cos^3 \theta - 3 \cos \theta \sin^2 \theta) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(3 \cos^2 \theta \sin \theta - \sin^3 \theta)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using de Moivre's theorem, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    z^3 &= (\cos \theta + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \theta)^3 \\[6pt]
    &= \cos 3\theta + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin 3\theta\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, using part (a) (i), we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{6.5em} \cos 3\theta &= \cos^3 \theta - 3 \cos \theta \sin^2 \theta \hspace{3em} \big[=\mathrm{Re}(z^3)\big] \\[6pt]
    \cos 3\theta &= \cos^3 \theta - 3 \cos \theta\hspace{0.1em}(1 - \cos^2 \theta) \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{\cos 3\theta = 4\cos^3 \theta - 3\cos \theta} \hspace{3.45em} \qref{(1)}
    $$

    and

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{6.5em} \sin 3\theta &= 3 \cos^2 \theta \sin \theta - \sin^3 \theta \hspace{3em} \big[=\mathrm{Im}(z^3)\big] \\[6pt]
    \sin 3\theta &= 3(1 - \sin^2 \theta) \sin \theta - \sin^3 \theta \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{\sin 3\theta = 3\sin \theta - 4\sin^3 \theta} \hspace{3.55em} \qref{(2)}
    $$


- Hence, using the identities $(1)$ & $(2)$ from part (a) (ii), we
deduce

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\sin 3\theta - \sin \theta}{\cos 3\theta + \cos \theta} &= \dfrac{(3\sin \theta - 4\sin^3\theta) - \sin \theta}{(4\cos^3 \theta - 3\cos\theta) + \cos \theta} \hspace{0.4em} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{2\sin \theta - 4\sin^3 \theta}{4\cos^3 \theta - 2\cos \theta} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{2\sin \theta\hspace{0.1em}(1 - 2\sin^2 \theta)}{2\cos \theta\hspace{0.1em}(2\cos^2 \theta - 1)} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\cancel{2}\sin \theta \hspace{0.1em}\cancel{\cos 2\theta}}{\cancel{2}\cos \theta \hspace{0.1em}\cancel{\cos 2\theta}} \\[10pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta} \\[14pt]
  &\answer{= \tan \theta}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Given that $\sin \theta = \dfrac{1}{3}$, for
$0 < \theta < \dfrac{\pi}{4}$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \cos \theta &= \dfrac{2\sqrt{2}}{3} \hspace{3.6em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the identities $(1)$ & $(2)$ from part (a) (ii), we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.85em} \tan 3 \theta &= \dfrac{\sin 3\theta}{\cos 3\theta} \\[7pt]
  &= \dfrac{3\sin \theta - 4\sin^3 \theta}{4\cos^3 \theta - 3\cos \theta} \\[7pt]
  &= \dfrac{3(1/3) - 4(1/3)^3}{4(2\sqrt{2}/3)^3 - 3(2\sqrt{2}/3)} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1 - 4/27}{64\sqrt{2}/27 - 2\sqrt{2}} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{27 - 4}{64\sqrt{2} - 54\sqrt{2}} \\[7pt]
  &= \dfrac{23}{10\sqrt{2}} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{23\sqrt{2}}{20}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 28
list.content: - Solve $2\sin(x+\ang{120}) = \sqrt{3}\cos(x + \ang{60})$, for $x \in [0,\ang{180}]$. [5] - Show that $\sin \ang{75} + \cos \ang{75} = \dfrac{\sqrt{6}}{2}$. [3] - Let $z = \sin 4\theta + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(1 - \cos 4\theta)$, for $z \in \mathbb{C}$, $\theta \in [0,\ang{90}]$. - Find the modulus and argument of $z$ in terms of $\theta$. - Hence find the fourth roots of $z$ in modulus-argument form. [14]
list.markScheme:
- Using the compound angle formulas for sine and cosine, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2\sin(x+\ang{120}) &= \sqrt{3}\cos(x + \ang{60}) \\[12pt]
  2\hspace{0.05em}(\sin x \cos \ang{120} + \cos x \sin \ang{120}) &= \sqrt{3}\hspace{0.05em}(\cos x \cos \ang{60} - \sin x \sin \ang{60}) \\[12pt]
  2\sin x \hspace{0.05em}(- \sin \ang{30}) + 2\cos x \cos \ang{30} &= \sqrt{3}\cos x \cos \ang{60} - \sqrt{3}\sin x \sin \ang{60} \\[6pt]
  2\sin x \bigg(\hspace{-0.3em}-\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg) + 2\cos x\bigg(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\bigg) &= \sqrt{3}\cos x \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg) - \sqrt{3}\sin x \bigg(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\bigg)  \\[6pt]
  -2\sin x + 2\sqrt{3}\cos x &= \sqrt{3}\cos x - 3\sin x  \\[12pt]
  \sin x &= -\sqrt{3}\cos x \\[12pt]
  \tan x &= -\sqrt{3} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.2em} \answer{x = \ang{120}}
  $$

- Using the compound angle formula for sine, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (\sin \ang{75} + \cos \ang{75})^2 &= (\sin \ang{75})^2 + (\cos \ang{75})^2 + 2\sin \ang{75}\cos \ang{75}\\[12pt]
  &= 1 + \sin \left(\ang{75} + \ang{75}\right) \\[12pt]
  &= 1 + \cos \ang{60} \\[7pt]
  &= 1 + \dfrac{1}{2} \\[4pt]
  &= \dfrac{6}{4} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if we take the
square root of both sides of the equality $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{\sin \ang{75} + \cos \ang{75} = \dfrac{\sqrt{6}}{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The modulus of $z$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} |z| &= \left[(\sin 4\theta)^2  + (1 - \cos 4 \theta)^2\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[5pt]
    &= \left[(\sin 4\theta)^2 + (\cos 4 \theta)^2 + 1 - 2\cos 4\theta\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[5pt]
    &= \left[2 - 2\cos 4 \theta\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[5pt]
    &= \left[2\hspace{0.05em}(1 - \cos 4\theta)\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[5pt]
    &= \left[2\big(1-(1 - 2\hspace{0.05em}(\sin 2\theta)^2\big)\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \hspace{2em} [\text{by double-angle formula}] \\[5pt]
    &= \left[4\hspace{0.05em}(\sin 2\theta)^2\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[10pt]
    &= 2\hspace{0.05em}|\hspace{-0.05em}\sin 2\theta\hspace{0.05em}| \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= 2\sin 2\theta} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $\sin 2\theta \geq 0$ for $\theta \in [0,\ang{90}]$}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Using the double-angle formulas for sine and cosine, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \tan \left(\arg z\right) &= \dfrac{1- \cos 4\theta}{\sin 4\theta} \hspace{2.4em} \\[4pt]
    &= \dfrac{1-\big[1 - 2(\sin 2\theta)^2\big]}{2\sin 2\theta\cos 2\theta} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{\sin 2\theta}{\cos 2\theta} \\[10pt]
    &= \tan 2\theta\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the argument of $z$ is
$\answer{\arg z = 2 \theta}$
  - Hence, using part (c) and de Moivre's theorem, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} z^\frac{1}{4} &= (2\sin 2\theta \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}2\theta)^\frac{1}{4} \\[12pt]
    &= \sqrt[4]{2\sin 2\theta}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\left(\dfrac{2\theta + 2k\pi}{4}\right) \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \sqrt[4]{2\sin 2\theta}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\left(\dfrac{\theta + k\pi}{2}\right)}\end{aligned}
    $$

    for $k = 0,1,2,3$.

list.title: Question 29
list.content: - Find the roots of $z^{16} = 1$ which satisfy the condition $0 < \arg(z) < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$, expressing your answer in the form $re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\theta}$, where $r, \theta \in \mathbb{R}^+$. [5] - Let $S$ be the sum of the roots found in part (a). - Show that $\mathrm{Re}(S) = \mathrm{Im}(S)$. - By writing $\dfrac{\pi}{8}$ as $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{4}$, find the value of $\cos \Big(\dfrac{\pi}{8}\Big)$ in the form $\dfrac{\sqrt{a + \sqrt{b}}}{c}$, where $a, b$ and $c$ are integers to be determined. - Hence, or otherwise, show that $S = \dfrac{1}{2}\big(\hspace{-0.1em}\sqrt{2 + \sqrt{2}} + \sqrt{2} + \sqrt{2 - \sqrt{2}}\hspace{0.1em}\big)\big(1+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\big)$. [11]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  z^{16} &= 1 \\[6pt]
  z^{16} &= \cos 0 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin 0\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using de Moivre's theorem, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9em} z &= (\cos 0 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin 0)^\frac{1}{16} \\[7pt]
  &= \cos\Big(\dfrac{2k\pi}{16}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\dfrac{2k\pi}{16}\Big) \\[4pt]
  &= \cos\Big(\dfrac{k\pi}{8}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\dfrac{k\pi}{8}\Big) \\[8pt]
  &= e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{k\pi}{8}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by Euler's formula}] \hspace{0.2em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  for $k = 0,1,2, \dots, 15$.
  Hence the roots of the equation $z^{16} = 1$ that satisfy
$0 < \arg(z) < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$ are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  k = 1 &: \hspace{0.525em}\answer{z_1 = e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{8}}} \\[6pt]
  k = 2 &: \hspace{0.525em}\answer{z_2 = e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{4}}} \\[6pt]
  k = 3 &: \hspace{0.525em}\answer{z_3 = e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{3\pi}{8}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - If we let $S = z_1 + z_2 + z_3$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \mathrm{Re}(S) &= \cos \Big(\frac{\pi}{8}\Big) + \cos \Big(\frac{\pi}{4}\Big) + \cos \Big(\frac{3\pi}{8}\Big) \\[6pt]
    \mathrm{Im}(S) &= \sin \Big(\frac{\pi}{8}\Big) + \sin \Big(\frac{\pi}{4}\Big) + \sin \Big(\frac{3\pi}{8}\Big)\end{aligned}
    $$

    Using the reflection law for cosine and sine, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \cos \Big(\frac{\pi}{8}\Big) &= \cos \Big(\dfrac{\pi}{2} - \frac{3\pi}{8}\Big) \\[6pt] 
    &= \sin \Big(\frac{3\pi}{8}\Big) \\[15pt]
    \cos \Big(\frac{\pi}{4}\Big) &= \cos \Big(\dfrac{\pi}{2} - \frac{\pi}{4}\Big) \\[6pt] 
    &= \sin \Big(\frac{\pi}{4}\Big) \\[15pt]
    \cos \Big(\frac{3\pi}{8}\Big) &= \cos \Big(\dfrac{\pi}{2} - \frac{\pi}{8}\Big) \\[6pt] 
    &= \sin \Big(\frac{\pi}{8}\Big)\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence we deduce
$\answer{\mathrm{Re}(S) = \mathrm{Im}(S)}$
  - Using the half-angle formula for cosine, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.5em} \cos \Big(\dfrac{\pi}{8}\Big) &= \cos \Big(\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{4}\Big) \\[7pt]
    &= \sqrt{\dfrac{1+\cos(\pi/4)}{2}} \\[7pt]
    &= \sqrt{\dfrac{1}{2}\Big[1 + \dfrac{\raisebox{-0.25em}{$\sqrt{2}$}}{2}\Big]} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{\sqrt{2 + \sqrt{2}}}{2}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Similarly, using the half-angle formula for sine, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \cos \Big(\dfrac{3\pi}{8}\Big) &= \sin \Big(\dfrac{\pi}{8}\Big) \\[9pt]
    &= \sin \Big(\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot\dfrac{\pi}{4}\Big) \\[7pt]
    &= \sqrt{\dfrac{1-\cos(\pi/4)}{2}} \\[7pt]
    &= \sqrt{\dfrac{1}{2}\Big[1 - \dfrac{\raisebox{-0.25em}{$\sqrt{2}$}}{2}\Big]} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{\sqrt{2 - \sqrt{2}}}{2}}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \mathrm{Re}(S) &= \cos \Big(\frac{\pi}{8}\Big) + \cos \Big(\frac{\pi}{4}\Big) + \cos \Big(\frac{3\pi}{8}\Big) \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{\sqrt{2 + \sqrt{2}}}{2} + \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2} + \dfrac{\sqrt{2 - \sqrt{2}}}{2} \\[8pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{2}\big(\hspace{-0.1em}\sqrt{2 + \sqrt{2}} + \sqrt{2} + \sqrt{2 - \sqrt{2}}\hspace{0.1em}\big)\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4.8em} S &= \mathrm{Re}(S) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\mathrm{Im}(S) \\[12pt]
    &= \mathrm{Re}(S) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\mathrm{Re}(S) \hspace{3em} [\text{since $\mathrm{Re}(S) = \mathrm{Im}(S)$}] \\[12pt]
    &= \mathrm{Re}(S)(1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{2}\big(\hspace{-0.1em}\sqrt{2 + \sqrt{2}} + \sqrt{2} + \sqrt{2 - \sqrt{2}}\hspace{0.1em}\big)\big(1+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\big)}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 30
list.content: - Solve the equation $z^3 = 27$, $z \in \mathbb{C}$, giving your answer in the form $z = r(\cos \theta + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \theta)$ and in the form $z = a + b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$. [6] - Consider the complex numbers $z_1 = -1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu} \text{ and } z_2 =\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\bigg[\mathrm{cos}\bigg(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\bigg)+\mathrm{i}\,\mathrm{sin}\bigg(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\bigg)\bigg]$ . - Write $z_1$ in the form $r(\cos \theta + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \theta)$. - Calculate $z_1z_2$ and write in the form $a + b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$. - Hence find the value of $\tan\left(\dfrac{\pi}{12}\right)$ in the form $c + d\sqrt{3}$ where $c,d \in \mathbb{Z}$. - Find the smallest $p \in \mathbb{Q}^+$ such that $(z_1z_2)^p$ is a positive real number. [11]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  z^3 &= 27\hspace{0.05em}(\cos 0 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin 0) \hspace{5.2em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using de Moivre's theorem, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.6em} z &= 27^{\frac{1}{3}}(\cos 0 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin 0)^\frac{1}{3} \\[5pt]
  &= 3\Big[\cos\Big(\dfrac{2k\pi}{3}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\dfrac{2k\pi}{3}\Big)\Big] \hspace{3em} [\text{for $k = 0,1,2$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the roots of the equation $z^3 = 27$ are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  k = 0 &: \hspace{0.525em}\answer{z = 3\hspace{0.05em}(\cos 0 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin 0) = 3} \\[9pt]
  k = 1 &: \hspace{0.525em}\answer{z = 3\Big[\cos\Big(\dfrac{2\pi}{3}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \Big(\dfrac{2\pi}{3}\Big)\Big] = -\dfrac{3}{2} + \dfrac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[10pt]
  k = 2 &: \hspace{0.525em}\answer{z = 3\Big[\cos\Big(\dfrac{4\pi}{3}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \Big(\dfrac{4\pi}{3}\Big)\Big] = -\dfrac{3}{2} - \dfrac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - If we write $z_1$ in modulus-argument form, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.8em} z_1 &= -1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\\[10pt]
    &= \sqrt{2}\bigg[\hspace{-0.25em}-\dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2} + \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\bigg] \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \sqrt{2}\Big[\cos\Big(\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\Big)\Big]} \end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we write $z_2$ in Cartesian form, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    z_2 &= \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\Big[\cos\Big(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\Big)\Big] \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\bigg[\dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\bigg] \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{4} + \dfrac{\sqrt{6}}{4}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, if we calculate $z_1z_2$ giving answer in Cartesian form,
we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    z_1z_2 &= (-1  + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})\bigg[\dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{4} + \dfrac{\sqrt{6}}{4}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\bigg] \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{4} - \dfrac{\sqrt{6}}{4}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}+ \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{4}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}- \dfrac{\sqrt{6}}{4} \\[9pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{-\sqrt{2} - \sqrt{6}}{4} + \dfrac{\sqrt{2}-\sqrt{6}}{4}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we calculate $z_1z_2$ giving answer in modulus-argument form,
we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.5em} z_1z_2 &= \bigg[\bcancel{\sqrt{2}}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\Big(\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\Big)\bigg]\bigg[\dfrac{1}{\bcancel{\sqrt{2}}} \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\Big(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\Big)\bigg] \\[5pt]
    &= \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\Big(\dfrac{3\pi}{4} + \dfrac{\pi}{3}\Big) \\[6pt]
    &= \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\Big(\dfrac{13\pi}{12}\Big) \\[6pt]
    &=  \cos\Big(\dfrac{13\pi}{12}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\dfrac{13\pi}{12}\Big) \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, comparing the expressions $(1)$ and $(2)$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \cos\Big(\dfrac{13\pi}{12}\Big) &= \dfrac{-\sqrt{2} - \sqrt{6}}{4} \\[6pt]
    \sin\Big(\dfrac{13\pi}{12}\Big) &= \dfrac{\sqrt{2} - \sqrt{6}}{4}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \tan\Big(\dfrac{\pi}{12}\Big) &= \tan\Big(\dfrac{13\pi}{12}\Big) \\[10pt]
    &= \sin\Big(\dfrac{13\pi}{12}\Big) \div \cos\Big(\dfrac{13\pi}{12}\Big) \hspace{2em} \\[8pt]
    &= \dfrac{\sqrt{2} - \sqrt{6}}{\bcancel{4}} \cdot \dfrac{\bcancel{4}}{-\sqrt{2} - \sqrt{6}} \\[5pt]
    &=\dfrac{\sqrt{6} - \sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{6} + \sqrt{2}} \cdot \dfrac{\sqrt{6} - \sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{6} - \sqrt{2}} \\[5pt]
    &= \dfrac{8 - 4\sqrt{3}}{4} \\[12pt]
    &\answer{= 2 - \sqrt{3}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The $p$ th power of $z_1z_2$ is a real
number if

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{7.4em} \sin \left(\arg \left((z_1z_2)^p\right)\right) &= 0 \\[12pt]
    \sin \left(p\arg \left(z_1z_2\right)\right) &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{by de Moivre's theorem}] \\[6pt]
    \sin \Big(\dfrac{13p\pi}{12}\Big) &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (b) (iii)}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the smallest $p \in \mathbb{Q}^+$ such that $(z_1z_2)^p$
is a positive real number is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.4em} \answer{p = \dfrac{24}{13}}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 33
list.content: - Use de Moivre's theorem to find the value of $\left[\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right)\right]^{12}$. [2] - Use mathematical induction to prove that $$ \hspace{3.5em} (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^n = \cos (n\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha) \hspace{1em} \text{for all } n \in \mathbb{Z}^+. $$ [6] Let $w = \cos \alpha + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha$. - Find an expression in terms of $\alpha$ for $w^n - (w^\ast)^n$, $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, where $w^\ast$ is the complex conjugate of $w$. [2] - - Show that $ww^\ast = 1$. - Write down and simplify the binomial expansion of $(w - w^\ast)^3$ in terms of $w$ and $w^\ast$. - Hence show that $\sin (3\alpha) = 3\sin \alpha - 4 \sin^3 \alpha$. [5] - Hence solve $4\sin^3\alpha + (2 \cos \alpha - 3) \sin \alpha = 0$ for $0 \leq \alpha \leq \pi$. [6]
list.markScheme:
- Using de Moivre's theorem, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \left[\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right)\right]^{12} &= \cos\Big(\dfrac{12\pi}{6}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \Big(\dfrac{12\pi}{6}\Big) \\[6pt]
  &= \cos 2\pi + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin 2\pi \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= 1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.6em} (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^n = \cos (n\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha) \hspace{2.5em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

Base case. For $n = 1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.3em} (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^1 &= \cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha \\[3pt]
&= \cos (1\cdot\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (1\cdot\alpha)\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^k = \cos (k\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (k\alpha) \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some $k \geq 1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{4em} (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^{k+1} = \cos ((k+1)\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin ((k+1)\alpha) \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.5em} &(\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^{k+1} = \\[5pt]
&= (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^k\cos \alpha - (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^k ({\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha) \\[6pt]
&= [\cos (k\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (k\alpha)]\cos \alpha - [\cos (k\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (k\alpha)] ({\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)  \hspace{2em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[6pt]
&= \cos (k\alpha)\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (k\alpha) \cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\cos (k\alpha) \sin \alpha - \sin (k\alpha)\sin \alpha \\[6pt]
&= [\cos (k\alpha)\cos \alpha - \sin (k\alpha)\sin \alpha] - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}[\sin (k\alpha) \cos \alpha + \cos (k\alpha) \sin \alpha]  \\[6pt]
&= \cos((k+1)\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin((k+1)\alpha) \hspace{2em} [\text{by compound angle formulas}]\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

- Using de Moivre's theorem and the identity $(2)$ from part
(b), we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  w^n - (w^\ast)^n &= (\cos \alpha + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^n - (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^n \\[6pt]
  &= [\hspace{0.05em}\cos (n\alpha) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha)] - [\hspace{0.05em}\cos (n\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha)] \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha)} \qref{(3)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The product of $w$ and its conjugate is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.2em} ww^\ast &= (\cos \alpha + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)(\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha) \\[6pt]
    &= \cos^2 \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\cos \alpha \sin \alpha + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha \cos \alpha + \sin^2 \alpha \\[6pt]
    &= \cos^2 \alpha + \sin^2 \alpha \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 1}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we simplify the binomial expansion of $(w - w^\ast)^3$, we
get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    (w - w^\ast)^3 &= w^3 - 3w^2w^\ast + 3w(w^\ast)^2 - (w^\ast)^3 \\[6pt]
    &= w^3 - 3w(ww^\ast) + 3w^\ast(ww^\ast) - (w^\ast)^3 \\[6pt]
    &= w^3 - 3w + 3w^\ast - (w^\ast)^3 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (d) (i)}] \hspace{0.7em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= w^3 - (w^\ast)^3 - 3(w - w^\ast)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Substituting $n = 1$ and $n = 3$ in the identity $(3)$ from part
(c), we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    n=1 &: \hspace{0.5em} w - (w^\ast) = 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha \\[6pt]
    n=3 &: \hspace{0.5em} w^3 - (w^\ast)^3 = 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (3\alpha)\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, from part d (ii), we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.3em} (w - w^\ast)^3 &= w^3 - (w^\ast)^3 - 3\hspace{0.05em}(w - w^\ast) \\[6pt]
    (2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^3 &= 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (3\alpha) - 3\hspace{0.05em}(2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha) \\[6pt]
    -8{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin^3 \alpha &= 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (3\alpha) - 6{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha \\[6pt]
    4\sin^3 \alpha &= -\sin (3\alpha) + 3 \sin \alpha \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{\sin (3\alpha) = 3 \sin \alpha -4\sin^3 \alpha} \hspace{0.9em}
    $$


- If we rewrite the given equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  4\sin^3\alpha + (2 \cos \alpha - 3) \sin \alpha &= 0 \\[6pt]
  2\sin \alpha \cos \alpha  &= 3\sin \alpha - 4\sin^3\alpha \\[7pt]
  \sin (2\alpha) &= \sin (3\alpha) \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (d) (iii)}] \hspace{1em} \qref{(4)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(4)$ for $\alpha$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.7em} \alpha &= 0 \hspace{0.75em}\text{or}\hspace{0.75em} 3\alpha = k\pi - 2\alpha \hspace{2.2em} [\text{where $k$ is an odd integer}] \\[7pt]
  \hspace{8.7em} \alpha &= 0 \hspace{0.75em}\text{or}\hspace{0.75em} \alpha = \dfrac{k\pi}{5} \hspace{2em} [\text{where $k = 1,3,5$ since $\alpha \in [0,\pi]$}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{\alpha = 0,\hspace{0.25em} \dfrac{\pi}{5},\hspace{0.25em} \dfrac{3\pi}{5},\hspace{0.25em} \pi} \hspace{8.55em}
  $$

list.title: Question 34
list.content: - Solve the equation $\sin (x + \ang{90}) = 2\cos(x - \ang{60})$, $\ang{0} < x < \ang{360}$. [5] - Show that $\sin \ang{15} + \cos \ang{15} = \dfrac{\sqrt{6}}{2}$. [4] - Let $z = 1 - \cos 4\theta - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin 4\theta$, for $z \in \mathbb{C}$, $0 < \theta < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$. - Find the modulus and argument of $z$. Express each answer in its simplest form. - Hence find the fourth roots of $z$ in modulus-argument form. [11]
list.markScheme:
- Using the compound angle formulas for sine and cosine, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sin\left(x + \ang{90} \right) &= 2\cos\left(x - \ang{60}\right) \\[14pt]
  \sin x \cos \ang{90} + \cos x \sin \ang{90} &= 2\cos x \cos \ang{60} + 2\sin x \sin \ang{60} \\[6pt]
  \sin x \left(0\right) + \cos x \left(1\right) &= 2\cos x \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg) + 2\sin x \bigg(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\bigg) \\[6pt]
  \cos x &= \cos x + \sqrt{3}\sin x \\[14pt]
  0 &= \sqrt{3}\sin x \\[14pt]
  \sin x &= 0 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.8em} \answer{x = \ang{180}}  \hspace{3em} [\text{since $\ang{0} < x < \ang{360}$}]
  $$

- Using the compound angle formula for sine, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.1em} \sin \ang{15} &=\sin\left(\ang{45} - \ang{30}\right) \\[14pt]
  &= \sin\ang{45}\cos\ang{30} - \cos \ang{45}\sin \ang{30} \\[8pt]
  &=\dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\cdot\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2} - \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{2} \\[4pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{6} - \sqrt{2}}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the compound
angle formula for cosine, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \cos \ang{15} &=\cos (\ang{45} - \ang{30}) \\[14pt]
  &= \cos\ang{45}\cos\ang{30} + \sin \ang{45}\sin \ang{30} \\[8pt]
  &=\dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\cdot\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2} + \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\cdot\dfrac{1}{2} \\[4pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{6} + \sqrt{2}}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sin \ang{15} + \cos \ang{15} &= \dfrac{\sqrt{6} - \sqrt{2}}{4} + \dfrac{\sqrt{6} + \sqrt{2}}{4} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{\sqrt{6}}{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The modulus of $z$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5em} |z| &= \big[(1-\cos 4\theta)^2 + (\sin 4\theta)^2\big]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[6pt]
    &= \big[1 - 2\cos 4\theta + (\cos 4\theta)^2 + (\sin 4\theta)^2\big]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[6pt]
    &= \big[2 - 2\cos 4\theta\big]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[6pt]
    &= \big[2 - 2\big(1 - 2\hspace{0.05em}(\sin 2\theta)^2\big)\big]^{\frac{1}{2}} \hspace{2em} [\text{by double-angle formula}] \\[6pt]
    &= \big[4\hspace{0.05em}(\sin 2\theta)^2\big]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[11pt]
    &= 2\hspace{0.05em}|\hspace{-0.05em}\sin 2\theta\hspace{0.05em}| \\[11pt]
    &\answer{= 2\sin 2\theta} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $\sin 2\theta > 0$ for $0 < \theta < \ang{90}$}] \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

    Using the double-angle formulas for sine and cosine, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \tan \left(\arg z \right)&= \dfrac{(-\sin 4\theta)}{1 - \cos 4\theta} \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{2\sin 2\theta \cos 2\theta}{1 - \big[1 - 2\hspace{0.05em}(\sin 2\theta)^2\big]} \\[5pt]
    &= -\dfrac{\cos 2\theta}{\sin 2\theta} \\[12pt]
    &= -\cot 2\theta \\[12pt]
    &= -\tan\left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} - 2\theta\right) \\[10pt]
    &=\tan\left(2\theta - \dfrac{\pi}{2}\right) \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the argument of $z$ is
$\answer{\arg z = 2\theta - \dfrac{\pi}{2}}$
  - Hence, using part c (i) and de Moivre's theorem, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    z^\frac{1}{4} &= \left[2\sin 2\theta \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\Big(2\theta - \dfrac{\pi}{2}\Big)\right]^\frac{1}{4} \\[8pt]
    &= \sqrt[4]{2\sin 2\theta} \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\bigg(\dfrac{2\theta - \pi/2 + 2k\pi}{4}\bigg) \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \sqrt[4]{2\sin 2\theta} \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\bigg(\dfrac{\theta}{2} - \dfrac{\pi}{8} + \dfrac{k\pi}{2}\bigg)}\end{aligned}
    $$

    for $k = 0,1,2,3$.

list.title: Question 35
list.content: The complex number $z$ is a root of the equation $|z+4i|=|z-10i|$. - Show that the imaginary part of $z$ is $3$.[2] - Let $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$ be two possible values of $z$ such that $|z|=6$. - If $\omega_1$ is in the first quadrant sketch both solutions on an Argand diagram. - Hence find the arguments of $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$.[4] A different complex number, $v$, is defined such that $$ \begin{align*} v&=\dfrac{\omega_{1}^k\,\omega_2}{-i} \end{align*} $$ Where $k$ is a real number that can take any value in the interval $-10\leq k \leq 10$ and $-\pi \leq \arg{(-i)} \leq \pi$. - - Find $\arg{(v)}$ in terms of $k$ and $\pi$. - Hence find all possible values of $k$ such that $v$ is a real number.[8]

list.title: Question 36
list.content: This questions will investigate a method to obtain Cardano's formula using elementary properties of complex numbers and algebraic expressions. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e10af45-5057-4e0b-a99d-9c029231b5d3/images/ea464ab6-a275-4781-9cd3-0b243a99f8b0/AA918%20-%20dia.png) - The roots, of magnitude $1$, described above can be written in polar form such that $\omega_n=\cos \theta + i \sin \theta$. The argument, $\theta$, is such that $0 \leq \theta \leq 2\pi$. - Show that $\omega_0=1$ and find the remaining roots, $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$, in polar form. - Show that $\omega_1 \omega_2 = 1$. - Show that $\omega_1^2+\omega_2^2 = \omega_1+\omega_2$. - Hence, show that $\omega_1+\omega_2 = - 1$ in Cartesian form. [7] Consider the cubic equation $x^3-3px+2q=0$ for $p$, $q\in \mathbb{R}$. Assume we can write it in a factorised form such that $x^3-3px+2q=(x+\alpha+\beta)(x+\omega_1\alpha+\omega_2\beta)(x+\omega_2\alpha+\omega_1\beta)$. - - Identify the roots of the factorised form above, find the product of the roots, then use the results from part (a) to show that $2q = \alpha^3+\beta^3$ Another formula for the roots $r_1$, $r_2$ and $r_3$ of the cubic equation $ax^3+bx^2+cx+d$ states that $r_1r_2+r_1r_3+r_2r_3=\dfrac{c}{a}\rule[-2mm]{0pt}{7mm}$. - Using the roots identified from part (b) (i), the formula above, and the results from part (a), show that $p=\alpha\beta$. - Using parts (b) (i) and (b) (ii), write $\alpha$ and $\beta$ in terms of $p$ and $q$. - Hence, show that $-\sqrt[3]{q+\sqrt{q^2-p^3}}-\sqrt[3]{q-\sqrt{q^2-p^3}}$ is a root of the cubic equation $x^3-3px+2q = 0$. [12] Now, consider a more general cubic equation $x^3+sx+t = 0$, where $s$, $t\in\mathbb{R}$. - - By substituting $s=-3p$ and $t=2q$ prove Cardano's formula, which states that $\sqrt[3]{-\dfrac{t}{2}+\sqrt{\dfrac{t^2}{4}+\dfrac{s^3}{27}}} + \sqrt[3]{-\dfrac{t}{2}-\sqrt{\dfrac{t^2}{4}+\dfrac{s^3}{27}}}$ is a root of the cubic equation $x^3+sx+t=0$. - Use Cardano's formula to find the exact solution to $x^3+6x+5=0$. - Using the substitution $z=x-1$ and Cardano's formula, find an exact solution to $z^3+3z^2-6=0$.[9]
